definition: Policies and programs that expand fair, affordable, and reliable access to safe drinking water for all populations, including peri-urban, rural, and marginalized communities.
Policies that improve household and community sanitation, sewerage, fecal sludge management, and hygiene practices to protect public health.
Policies and investments to collect, treat, and safely reuse wastewater (including greywater), reducing pollution and closing water loops.
Integrated management of surface and groundwater, aquifers, and river basins, including allocation, protection, and long-term planning of water resources.
Measures that prepare water and sanitation systems for climate impacts such as floods, droughts, sea-level rise, and extreme weather events.
Standards, monitoring, and enforcement to control contamination of water bodies from urban, industrial, agricultural, and tourism-related sources.
Use of ecosystems (wetlands, reefs, mangroves, forests) and nature-based solutions to improve water security, protect coasts, and enhance biodiversity.
Policies focused on extending and improving water and sanitation services in rural areas, small towns, and dispersed communities.
Planning and investment in urban water supply, sewerage, stormwater drainage, and flood management infrastructure.
Measures that link water and sanitation systems to disaster preparedness, emergency response, and rapid recovery after shocks.
Financing, building, and maintaining water, sanitation, and drainage infrastructure, with emphasis on asset management and service continuity.
Legal frameworks, sector governance, utility reform, and capacity building for regulators, ministries, and service providers.
Tariff design, subsidies, blended finance, and fiscal mechanisms that ensure financial sustainability while protecting vulnerable users.
Systems for gathering, analyzing, and publishing data on service coverage, performance, water quality, and resource status.
Approaches that address differentiated water and sanitation needs of women, children, indigenous peoples, and other vulnerable groups.
Use of innovative technologies, digital tools, and new business models to improve water and sanitation planning, operations, and service delivery.
Policies that connect water and sanitation with solid waste management, recycling, circular economy, and reduction of waste streams that affect water bodies.
Programs and campaigns that promote behavior change, awareness, and community participation in water, sanitation, and ecosystem protection.
